close_symbols: struct Request (definition: members pp, session, post_url, ...)
struct Session (definition: member start and lifetime semantics)
pages (the global pages[] array and the element type: pages[].url, pages[].handler, pages[].handler_cls, pages[].mime)
post_iterator (POST callback that can set request->post_url)
explanation:
The MISRA rule in question concerns use of string.h functions (here: strcmp and strlen in create_response) and requires proving those calls cannot read beyond object bounds or read non-terminated data. For that analysis we need the following symbols and why:

- struct Request (definition: members pp, session, post_url, ...)
  - create_response reads request->post_url in a strcmp; we must know the type, where post_url is stored, and its lifetime/ownership to ensure it is a valid NUL-terminated string when strcmp is called.

- struct Session (definition: member start and lifetime semantics)
  - Even though Session does not participate in string ops directly, knowing its definition and lifetime ensures create_response does not inadvertently dereference invalid memory that might affect control flow to string usage (minor, but useful for full safety reasoning).

- pages (the global pages[] array and element type: pages[].url, pages[].handler, pages[].handler_cls, pages[].mime)
  - create_response iterates pages[i].url and calls strcmp(pages[i].url, url). We must see pages[] contents and type to verify pages[i].url is either NULL or a NUL-terminated string allocated/stored safely (no out-of-bounds). Also need to confirm there is a NULL sentinel as used in the loop.

- METHOD_ERROR (definition / contents)
  - strlen(METHOD_ERROR) is called; we must verify METHOD_ERROR points to a valid NUL-terminated buffer (likely a literal) so strlen cannot read out-of-bounds.

- MHD_HTTP_METHOD_POST, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD (definitions / string constants)
  - create_response compares method with these constants via strcmp. We must know these symbols are valid NUL-terminated C strings (and not, e.g., non-terminated buffers) so strcmp won't read past bounds.

- post_iterator (the POST field iterator callback)
  - The POST processing flow can set request->post_url. To ensure strcmp(request->post_url, url) is safe we must inspect post_iterator to see how it writes/allocates post_url and whether the result is NUL-terminated and within allocated bounds.

- MHD_post_process (prototype and behavior)
  - create_response calls MHD_post_process to feed POST data to the post processor. To reason about when post_iterator has produced a post_url and its validity (and whether create_response later calls strcmp on it), we need to know how MHD_post_process invokes the callback(s) and when it reports completion (so create_response only compares valid strings).

- post_process_urlencoded and post_process_multipart (implementations)
  - The static call graph shows these routines are involved in POST processing. They may allocate, fill or mutate buffers used for post_url or other strings. Their behavior (how they terminate strings, maximum lengths, and allocation strategy) is required to prove strcmp/strlen calls in create_response do not read beyond bounds.

Together these symbols let the next analyst verify that every pointer passed to strcmp/strlen in create_response (method, url, pages[i].url, request->post_url, METHOD_ERROR) is guaranteed to be a valid pointer to a NUL-terminated object whose bounds are respected, satisfying the MISRA <string.h> rule.
